summary: alphaviruses (family Togaviridae, genus Alphavirus) include 30 identified viral species. most alphaviruses are transmitted by mosquito vectors to various vertebrate hosts, especially birds, rodents, and primates. many alphaviruses cause disease in vertebrate animals with the potential to emerge into humans or domesticated animals via epidemic and epizootic cycles. the alphavirus 5′ and 3′ UTRs contain distinct core promoter elements for both minus- and plus-strand RNA synthesis. a conserved 51-nucleotide element important for virus replication exists near the start of the coding portion of the non-structural protein 1 gene. alphavirus 5′ and 3′ UTRs contain non-segmented, single stranded RNA genomes of 11–12 kb, with a type 0 cap (N7mGppp) at the 5′ end and a poly(A) tail at the 3′ end. alphavirus genomes appear to the host cell as messenger RNA (mRNA) for immediate translation upon entry into the cytoplasm. conserved sequence elements (CSE) can be found in two additional regions of the Sindbis virus (SINV) genome. first, a conserved 51-nucleotide element important for virus replication exists near the start of the coding portion of the non-structural protein 1 (nsP1) gene. this element is dispensable for replication in vertebrate cells, but important for replication in mosquito cells. the 5′ UTRs range in length from 27 (Salmon Alphavirus (SAV) to 85 (Semliki Forest Virus (SFV)) nucleotides, and the 3′ UTRs range from 87 (SAV) to 723 (CHIKV) nucleotides. aquatic alphaviruses without a known arthropod vector contain the shortest UTRs (5′-: 27 nucleotides; 3′-: 87–130 chikungunya virus 3′ UTR has a number of direct repeats (DRs 1, 2, and 3), which occur in lineage-specific patterns. the chikungunya virus 3′ UTR diverged from the east/Central/South African (ECSA) enzootic lineage about 100 years ago. the evolution of the CHIKV 3′ UTR is probably shaped by the fitness trade-offs between mammalian and mosquito hosts. it is not known if the deleterious effect of the longer 3′ UTR for replication in mammalian cells is caused by negative interactions with mammalian host factors. the estimated year of the most recent common ancestor (MRCA: mean and the 95% HPD values) of each clade is labeled left to the node. the 3′ UTR structures are shown next to each lineage. alphaviruses in the Semliki Forest (SF) complex contains the longest UTRs with the greatest diversity in length (5′-: 76–85 nucleotides; 3′-: 227–713 nucleotides). the longest complex contains the longest UTRs with the greatest diversity in length (5′-: 76–85 nucleotides; 3′-: 78–184 nucleotides). the evolution of the chikungunya virus 3′ UTR is probably shaped by the fitness trade-offs between mammalian and mosquito hosts. the evolution of the CHIKV 3′ UTR is probably shaped by the fitness trade-offs between mammalian and mosquito hosts. cal exchange of the 3′ UTR of ECSA and Asian strain suggested that the fitness of the Asian lineage 3′ UTR is significantly lower than that of its ancestor, the ECSA lineage 3′ UTR, in both mammalian and mosquito hosts. findings suggest that a population bottleneck resulted from a founder effect when CHIKV was introduced into Asia by an infected traveler. sequence alignment, shown next to each lineage, is shown by white blocks. in the Asian lineage, two distinct derived differences are observed: (1) duplication of DR3 and (2) duplication the of DR(1 + 2) region. fitness trade-offs and population bottlenecks likely have contributed to evolution of the CHIKV 3′ UTR. messenger RNA of higher eukaryotes and viruses that utilize cap-dependent translation also contain additional 2′-O-methylation of the first transcribed nucleotide to create a Cap 1 structure. alphavirus RNA is translated in a cap-dependent manner, but lacks this additional 2′-O-methylation modification. eIF4E and eIF4F differentially associate with the genomic and subgenomic 5′ UTRs. eIF4G is cleaved by host (caspase-3) or viral proteins. eIF2 is phosphorylated by PKR, leading to global inhibition of mRNA translation. the alphavirus 5′ UTR forms stable secondary structures and mutagenesis studies have shown that both the sequence and structure of the UTR modulates replication. both the sequence and the thermodynamic stability of the 5′ stem structure regulate replication, as mutations that alter the thermodynamic stability of the stem or change the sequence but not the stability of the stem compromise replication. the addition of AU-rich sequences to the 5′ terminus is mediated by the RdRp. the revertants may arise from either the adenylyltransferase or error-prone polymerase activity of nsP4 or synergistic activity of both. despite their conserved features, the 5′ UTRs among alphaviruses form distinct secondary structures, which may affect function and compatibility. 5′ UTR and 3′ UTR incompatibility among different alphaviruses also suggested by replication experiments with VEEV/SINV and EEEV/SINV chimeric viruses. replicase proteins from different alphaviruses lack promiscuity, and may interact differentially with RNA sequences. cytoplasmic viruses generate Cap 1 structures on their mRNA by encoding their own viral 2′-O-methyltransferases (e.g., Flaviviruses, Coronaviruses, Poxviruses), snatching caps from host mRNA (e.g., Orthomyxoviruses and Bunyaviruses), or utilizing cap-independent translation (e.g., Picornaviruses, Caliciviruses, the structure of the alphavirus 5′ UTR antagonizes the antiviral function of Ifit1 by inhibiting binding to viral RNA. this is an impressive feat for a very short (85 bases or less in different alphaviruses) untranslated region. alphavirus genomic and subgenomic RNAs are modified at the 5′ termini by the addition of a 7-methylguanosine (m7G) cap structure (Cap 0), which promotes RNA stability and translation of viral transcripts. in eukaryotic cells, mRNA capping proceeds as follows: RNA triphosphatase cleaves nascent RNA (pppNp-RNA) at the gamma phosphate position to yield messenger RNA of higher eukaryotes and many viruses that utilize cap-dependent translation also contain additional 2′-O-methylation of the first transcribed nucleotide to create a Cap 1 structure. however, the 5′ UTR sequence or structure is not reported to modulate the efficiency of alphavirus m7G capping. key host translation initiation factors eIF4E and eIF4F differ from genomic and subgenomic 5′ UTRs. eIF4G is cleaved by host (caspase-3) or viral proteins. eIF2 is phosphorylated by PKR. alphavirus 5′ UTR forms stable secondary structures and mutagenesis studies have shown that both the sequence and structure of the UTR modulates replication. the AU dinucleotide at the very terminus of the 5′ UTR is required for replication, independent of its ability to base pair. the revertants containing AU-rich sequences may arise from either the adenylyltransferase or error-prone polymerase activity of nsP4 or synergistic activity of both. despite their conserved features, the 5′ UTRs among alphaviruses form distinct secondary structures, which may affect function and compatibility. a single point mutation at nucleotide position 3 compromised virulence in immunocompetent mice. sequence deletions and point mutations at nucleotides 5 and 8 within the 5′ UTR of SINV and analogous point mutations at positions 21, 35, and 42 within the 5′ UTR of SFV also alter pathogenicity. Ifit1 is up-regulated rapidly and to high levels following type I IFN treatment or viral infection. many cytoplasmic viruses generate Cap 1 structures on their mRNA by encoding their own viral 2′-O-methyltransferases (e.g., Flaviviruses, Coronaviruses, Poxviruses), or utilizing cap-independent translation. ifit1 restricts viral replication, in part, by competing with host translation factors eIF4E and eIF4F for binding to viral RNA. 5′ UTRs of alphavirus RNAs have major roles in promoter function, translational initiation, translational shut-off and avoidance of innate immune mechanisms. a 19-nucleotide CSE at the end of the alphavirus 3′ UTR immediately prior to the poly (A) tail serves as the promoter for negative strand synthesis. the cytosine at 1 nucleotide has been identified as the site of initiation for negative strand synthesis. poly(A) tail functions in conjunction with the CSE to support negative strand synthesis as well as efficient translation. a minimum of 11–12 residues in the poly(A) tail is required for efficient production of negative strand RNA. in mammalian cells, the PABP bound to the poly(A) tail interacts with translation initiation factors bound to the cap structure at the 5′ UTR. polyadenylation of newly synthesized cellular mRNA occurs in the nucleus immediately after transcription. for alphaviruses, viral replication occurs in the cytoplasm and separate mechanism exists to polyadenylate the viral RNA. however, subsequent experiments with SINV did not confirm the presence of sufficient poly(U) sequence in the UTR that would promote addition of a poly(A) tail. serial passage of EEEV in BHK cells results in a similar deletion in the 3′ UTR. a 7–8 nucleotide seed sequence in the 5′ end of the miRNAs binds to complementary sequences in the 3′ UTR of cellular mRNAs. microRNA expression is regulated transcriptionally in a cell-specific manner. removal of the miR-142-3p binding sites rescues viral translation and replication in myeloid cells in vitro and in vivo. the interaction of miR-142-3p and EEEV demonstrates how a host miRNA can influence viral replication through cellular tropism. three of the four miR-142-3p binding sites in the 3′ UTR have perfect seed sequence matches to miR-142-3p. those with longer UTRs have the potential for a greater number of miRNA binding sites. the presence of highly specific sequences that result in restriction of RNA viruses presents a conundrum, as viruses should readily mutate to eliminate these sites. alphavirus 3′ UTR also has an important role in viral replication and adaptation to new replication environments in mosquito and mammalian cells. deletion of 31–293 nucleotides in SINV reduces viral replication in mosquito cells but not in chicken cells. this region of the 3′ UTR is important for vector infection. a small number of substitution mutations in miR-142-3p binding sites in EEEV markedly affected mosquito replication competence. binding of the cellular HuR protein to high affinity sites in the alphavirus 3′ UTR region impacts both cellular and viral gene expression during infection. most alphaviruses, except CHIKV, o’nyong-nyong virus (ONNV) and Ross River virus (RRV) contain a U-rich sequence (40 nucleotides mRNAs that normally rely on HuR protein are destabilized and fail to accumulate. these effects are due primarily to the viral 3′ UTR. presence of large amounts of an alphavirus 3′ UTR in infected cells can cause substantial changes in cellular gene expression that likely impact cellular homeostasis. the poly(A) tail functions in conjunction with the CSE to support negative strand synthesis as well as efficient translation. a minimum of 11–12 residues in the poly(A) tail is required for efficient production of negative strand RNA. adaptation to replication in mosquito vectors drives the retention of the RSEs in the 3′ UTR. deletions in the RSEs result in the poor replication of the Asian lineages in mosquito vectors. the 3′ UTR of SINV has no effect on viral replication in chicken embryonic fibroblasts. deletion of 260 nucleotides from the 3′ UTR of EEEV has no effect on viral replication in baby hamster kidney (BHK) or vero cells. miR-142-3p repression minimizes induction of type I IFN and other innate immune effectors. this allows EEEV to replicate essentially undetected by host defense responses. removal of the miR-142-3p binding sites rescues viral translation and replication in myeloid cells in vivo. alphavirus 3′ UTRs range from 77 to 609 nucleotides. only a small fraction of nucleotides including the CSE and HuR binding sites are essential for replication of some alphaviruses in mammalian cells. the interaction of miR-142-3p and EEEV 3′ UTR may not have been identified. therefore down-regulating the activity of miRNA systems in single cell types is unlikely to reveal the complex effects of miRNAs on virus tropism and disease. deletion of 31–293 nucleotides in SINV reduces viral replication in mosquito cells but not in chicken cells. a small number of substitution mutations in miR-142-3p binding sites in EEEV markedly affected mosquito replication competence. weaver and coworkers have proposed that elements in the 3′ UTR can be associated with virus adaptation to new reservoir hosts. the presence of large amounts of an alphavirus 3′ UTR in infected cells can cause substantial changes in cellular gene expression that likely impact cellular homeostasis. the presence of large amounts of an alphavirus 3′ UTR in infected cells can cause substantial changes in cellular gene expression that likely impact cellular homeostasis.
